The fact that many people and groups use technological advances to accumulate mountains of wealth without equally contributing back to the society for which it was built upon is a social issue not an issue with the technological advance itself.
It seemingly is what it is until we as a human race decide to change it 'socially'.
Similarly there might be people doing research into the impacts of their ai products on user behaviour which might really value the combination of social science and ai knoweldge.

I recall a recent talk by a UC Berkeley professor specializing in CV, Alyosha Efros, IIRC, the main theme of which was: Ask not 'what is this?', ask 'what is this like?' BTW, Bongard problems seem like a far better test for intelligence than the vague Turing test.
In my own field, the structuralist grammar of people like Chomsky has been all but dethroned by the lexical grammar of people like Halliday.
Languages are not clean little arrangements of meaning; they have pragmatics and idiomaticity that come into play, much of which is just cultural.
I guess it is just very difficult to combine these, but things such as Bayesian networks and Pearl's other work on causality are a nice step in the right direction.

Imagine if it were possible to split the atom using cheap, over the counter materials and plans readily found online? I'm sure most users would respect that power and use it only for beneficial things like electricity generation, but you know that someone somewhere would end up adding when they should have subtracted and nuke their neighbor.
Not closed source, per se, but definitely limited to certified individuals and subject to regulatory oversight.
Wish that 2 billion would be put toward oversight and regulation and public education.
Our society is about to get very strange with all this intrusive technology and no oversight.
But we should definitely not be freely distributing this potentially dangerous technology to just anyone.

What if the people who make it use it for evil? If it's open source and a lot of people are working on it, then it will be very difficult for a few bad apples to make something that greatly outperforms all other intelligent implementations.
I think it's a strange assumption that people fall in to, that AGI would immediately be used for bad.
What kind of military power could Joe Blow muster from his basement? There was an interesting Sci Fi book called Rule 34 (by Charles Stross).
Whether or not OpenCog is a good approach to creating AGI doesn't really answer this question.
AGI should be closed source because then WORLD DOMINATION MWA HA HA HA HA HA : D But seriously.
It allows the general public to improve upon the code, making a more intelligent AI, more efficient speed wise, memory wise, or use less electricity.
It allows the general public to see whether there is malicious code in it, e.g code that gives the AI a political bias, or a malicious goal of the SkyNet sort.

I think the trade off you're mentioning is then between my last advantage and the disadvantage: Do we trust an organisation not to produce a malicious hard AI, or do we trust the general public not to produce a malicious AI? If the source code is released, everyone has the power to create an AI of their own with their own goals in mind.

Much like humans then, only the AIs will more easily be able to increase their own intelligence and quickly surpass humans, but the AIs could come to a reasonably balanced society much like we have now, if they realise that this society is a win win for all of them.
If this is a neutral organisation, then we're in utopia, with the AI doing all our thinking for us, working for the humans and working together.
Permitting strong AI source to be owned by an organization is not a far cry from enslavement of the only other full sentient we would met, and that would be a damn shame.
Do you let your children play with knives matches scissors and the like before they know any better than to hurt themselves or others.
It's an interesting thought, but I am not sure that even strong AI necessarily includes desires or self referential goals such as freedom, privacy, or even survival.

I believe that this will not change for many years because this is the nature of the project by design, where emphasis is placed on choosing and tuning components for integration, and on experimenting with novel algorithms and their variations, one research bit at a time.
Strong AI should NOT be given to the public.
Empathy is extremely important when it comes to decision making processes quite often.
